issues.title: RsEmpty status should be 204 not 200
issues.body:
Empty success response should have the status `204 NoContent` according to https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230 see "3.3.  Message Body" section

>    All 1xx (Informational), 204 (No Content), and 304 (Not Modified)
   responses do not include a message body.  All other responses do
   include a message body, although the body might be of zero length.

so it would be more logical to use 204 status for `RsEmpty` and use `200` status as default only in `RsWithBody`.

issues.title: There are some classes not closed to inheritance (final)
issues.body: The classes `PsAll`, `TkMethods`, `RsFailure`, `Transform`, `Utf8InputStreamReader`, `Utf8InputStreamWriter`, `Utf8PrintStream`, `RqSimple` and `RsSimple` aren't close to inheritance (`final` keyword). So, following the EO principles, they should be.

issues.title: Utf8InputStreamReader/Utf8OutputStreamWriter have wrong names
issues.body: Proper object name should say what object is representing, not what it [does]( https://www.yegor256.com/2015/03/09/objects-end-with-er.html). These two classes need refactoring.

  It is recommended that the compiler be upgraded.

issues.title: Upgrade to qulice 0.17.3
issues.body:
New qulice version brings following important changes:
- removal of `@author` tag (it is prohibited now)
- removal of `@version` tag (it is prohibited now)
- license header should start with `/*` instead of `/**`  - this will fix problem with IntelliJ reporting it as a javadoc that is not attached to any class
- checkstyle validation performance improvement (speedup of ~ 10%)
And few minor formatting changes.

Please upgrade the qulice and fix the new problems found.

issues.title: CcAes issues
issues.body:
`CcAes` generates random `IV` and use it for all requests to encrypt identity cookie. It produces two issues:

1. On server restart old cookies becomes invalid because `IV` regenerated, and all users need re-login.
2. It has some security issues: https://security.stackexchange.com/a/1097

Suggestion:
I'd make IV random for each request and add it to cookie (because IV doesn't need to be a secret [by design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_cipher_modes_of_operation#Initialization_vector_.28IV.29)), it prevents any data leakage. Also I'd append HMAC of whole cookie value, including IV and encrypted data, it prevents encrypted text modification attacks.
So cookie structure may look like this:
```
[-----IV----][---aes(src)---][---hmac(IV+aes(src))---]
```

issues.title: Codacy Quality Review do not recognize Matcher.asserThat in junit tests
issues.body:
There is Codacy, configured for the Takes project. However, it does not see assertions from hamcrest. If you look at [know issues](https://app.codacy.com/app/github_90/takes/issues/index?&filters=W3siaWQiOiJDYXRlZ29yeSIsInZhbHVlcyI6WyJDb2RlIFN0eWxlIl19XQ==) by Codacy there are 384 issues. And most of them telling that
> JUnit tests should include assert() or fail()

That's why many PRs showing that they have failing Codacy build, as we using asserts from Hamcrest, not the junit ones. This is just pointless noise in PR, so I propose to:
* Either fix Codacy, so that it will respect the assertions from hamcrest
* Or delete Codacy check from PRs as it seems to be redundant. We already have all necessary checks done by Qulice and Travis and AppVeyor builds should be enough.

issues.title: Anchor part of query handled incorrectly by `Href`
issues.body:
currently `Href` produces some weird results for links with anchor

### First example test case

```java
MatcherAssert.assertThat(
    new Href("http://example.com/?a=1#hello").toString(),
    Matchers.equalTo("http://example.com/?a=1#hello")
);
```
```log
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expected: "http://example.com/?a=1#hello"
     but: was "http://example.com/?a=1#h?a=1"
Expected :http://example.com/?a=1#hello
Actual   :http://example.com/?a=1#h?a=1
 <Click to see difference>
```

### Second example test case

```java
URI uri = URI.create("http://example.com/?a=1#hello");
MatcherAssert.assertThat( // This works as intended and produces right string
    uri.toString(),
    Matchers.equalTo("http://example.com/?a=1#hello")
);
MatcherAssert.assertThat(
    new Href(uri.toString()).toString(),
    Matchers.equalTo("http://example.com/?a=1#hello")
);
```
```log
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expected: "http://example.com/?a=1#hello"
     but: was "http://example.com/?a=1#h?a=1"
Expected :http://example.com/?a=1#hello
Actual   :http://example.com/?a=1#h?a=1
 <Click to see difference>
```

issues.title: TkRedirect should carry on the query and the fragment
issues.body:
When I'm doing this:

```
Response rsp = new TkRedirect("http://www.google.com/abc?b=2").act(
  new RqFake("GET", "/hi?a=1#test")
);
```

The `Location` header in the response should be equal to:

```
http://www.google.com/abc?b=2&a=1#test
```

At the moment it is equal to:


```
http://www.google.com/abc?b=2
```

issues.title: OutputStream in RsPrint may fail to flush() incase of IOException
issues.body:
The current implementation of the methods in ```org.takes.rs.RsPrint``` should be wrapped by a ```try-finally``` block to ensure that the ```OutputStream``` makes a call the ```#flush()``` method incase of an ```IOException```.

This will ensure that data held in the ```OutputStream``` before the ```Exception``` happened is written out to their intended destination.

issues.title: transient is not needed anymore
issues.body:
`transient` requirement has been removed from qulice. Please remove it everywhere where it was not added explicitly (e.g. in case of `Serializable` classes).

Also remove `of` parameter from all `@EqualsAndHashCode`, it was there because we had transient fields and we constantly were forgetting to add new fields there, now it won't be needed. (check tests for `EqualsVerifier.ignoredFields` for cases where `of` is still needed in the class under test).

Also in case of tests that check equals/hashCode contract using `EqualsVerifier`, remove `suppress(Warning.TRANSIENT_FIELDS)`.

issues.title: Get rid of StandardCharsets.UTF_8
issues.body:
There are many classes in the code base that rely on the public constant _StandardCharsets.UTF_8_ which is not a good solution for data duplication because:
1. It introduces coupling between all those classes and _StandardCharsets_ such that if the value is modified or simply removed those classes won't work properly anymore or won't even compile.
2. it reduces the global cohesion of those classes as they have to add their own semantics to this external constant with no real meaning instead of focusing on their own task .

More details [here](http://www.yegor256.com/2015/07/06/public-static-literals.html) and/or [Section 2.5 of the book Elegant Objects](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1519166915/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1519166915&linkCode=as2&tag=yegor256com-20&linkId=RMGEO4ESPM4CGD3O).

issues.title: Use String.split if the separator is only one character long
issues.body:
Using _String.split_ if the separator is only one character long (normal character or a backslash followed by a special character) is very fast as it is not treated internally as a regular expression but if the separator is a real regular expression it will internally compile the regular expression at each call which has a significant cost in term of performances.  In that case we are supposed to use a field _private static final_ of type Pattern which is possible because a Pattern is Immutable/thread safe and use this field to call _split(input)_ instead of doing _input.split(regexp)_.

So for example in my laptop calling 1 M times _split("\s")_ takes **more than 20 seconds** and doing the same thing with a pre-created Pattern object takes **9.4 seconds** which represents a performance **improvement of more than 50 %**.

issues.title: String.replaceAll should never be called
issues.body:
There are several places in the source code where the method _String.replaceAll_ (at least in _MediaType_ and _Href_) is called. It should be avoided mostly for performance reasons because it internally compiles the regular expression at each call. In that case we are supposed to use a field _private static final_ of type Pattern which is possible because a Pattern is Immutable/thread safe and use this field to call _matcher(input).replaceAll(replacement)_ instead of calling _input.replaceAll(replacement)_.

So for example in my laptop calling 1 M times _replaceAll("/$", "")_ takes about **30 seconds** and doing the same thing with a pre-created Pattern object takes **less than 20 seconds** which represents a performance **improvement of more than 30 %**.

issues.title: New qulice suppresion cleanups
issues.body:
In qulice used currently in project there are two changes that result in less strict rules:
- `DoNotUseThreads` PMD check is disabled
- `UseConcurrentHashMap` PMD check is disabled.

As a result all suppressions of above rules should be removed, more over all usages of `ConcurrentMap` and `ConcurrentHashMap` should be reviewed and all unnecessary (single thread access) usages replaced with `Map` and `HashMap`.

issues.title: Remove all 'null' usages in code
issues.body:
Takes advertises itself as a library without any `null`. That's not true, I see at least 26 [`null` usages](https://github.com/yegor256/takes/search?l=java&q=null) in Java code.

I'd expect removing `null` from as many places as possible and replacing them with alternatives. 
If some external API actually demands `null` and there's no workaround, we need to admit it in README, and say about few exceptions related to bad external APIs.

I'm fine to solve that issue with PDD approach.

issues.title: org.takes.facets.auth.PsByFlag::enter throws unchecked exception on invalid URLs
issues.body:
See https://github.com/yegor256/netbout/issues/877. If PsByFlag encounters an invalid URL it throws an unchecked exception that make the request handling fail.

Therefore org.takes.misc.Href should catch the unchecked exception from URI.create in line 73 and rethrow it as a checked one so that programmers actually get informed that the method can fail. Then I a suggest a catch for this exception in org.takes.facets.auth.PsByFlag::enter. If the URI is not malformed it cannot match and so an empty Identity should be returned.

issues.title: RsFlash doesn't allow to set the expiration time for the cookie

```

It would be great to be able to set the expiration time for the cookie

[HmRqHeader](https://github.com/yegor256/takes/blob/master/src/main/java/org/takes/facets/hamcrest/HmRqHeader.java) produces very confusing error message in case of mismtach:

Expected: entry containing ["Content-Length"->"102"]
     but: was <org.takes.rq.RqWithHeader@5679c7b2>
```

Ideally HmRqHeader implementation it should be very similar to [HmRsHeader](https://github.com/yegor256/takes/blob/master/src/main/java/org/takes/facets/hamcrest/HmRsHeader.java)

issues.title: RqSocket getLocalAddress and getRemoteAddress can throw UnknownHostException
issues.body:
BkBasic puts headers X-Takes-LocalAddress and X-Takes-RemoteAddress with slashes '/':

```
X-Takes-LocalAddress: /127.0.0.1
X-Takes-LocalPort: 8080
X-Takes-RemoteAddress: /127.0.0.1
X-Takes-RemotePort: 43727
```

Thats why RqSocket getLocalAddress and getRemoteAddress throws an exception:

```
java.net.UnknownHostException: /127.0.0.1: unknown error
  at java.net.Inet6AddressImpl.lookupAllHostAddr(Native Method)
  at java.net.InetAddress$2.lookupAllHostAddr(InetAddress.java:928)

  at java.net.InetAddress.getAllByName(InetAddress.java:1192)

  at java.net.InetAddress.getByName(InetAddress.java:1076)
  at org.takes.rq.RqSocket.getLocalAddress(RqSocket.java:57)
```

issues.title: RqMultipart parts should have Content-Length
issues.body: RqMultipart implementation decodes HTTP multipart FORM data and breaks (represents) the different parts into separate requests. These requests have bodies but don't precise a content length in the header. Every part should have its proper `Content-Length` header, in order to be treated as a valid request.

right now Takes doesn't allow to set the default header on the request

issues.title: ReadableByteChannel in org.takes.rq.RqMultipart.Base never closes
Refactoring of RqHeaders
issues.body:
Currently RqHeaders has following methods to work with HTTP headers:

```
/**
 * Get single header.
 *
 * @param key Header name
 * @return List of values (can be empty)
 * @throws IOException If fails
 */
Iterable<String> header(CharSequence key) throws IOException;

/**
 * Get all header names.
 *
 * @return All names
 * @throws IOException If fails
 */
Iterable<String> names() throws IOException;
```

However, working with Iterables not really convenient. Example: in order to check if some header exists I have to write something like this:

```
new RqHeaders.Base(req)
                    .header(header)
                    .iterator()
                    .hasNext();
```

Not very clear and obvious. 
At the same time internally RqHeaders implementations contain a kind of multimap - header name to list of values. I think it would be useful to have a couple of additional methods:

```
Set<String> namesSet();
List<String> getHeader(String header);
```

issues.title: RqLive must pay attention to Content-Length header.
issues.body:
Current version of `RqLive`  doesn't pay attention to `Content-Length` header, but it has to. For keep-alive connections after `Content-Length` bytes there can be second request (third request and so on, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_persistent_connection).

If there is no `Content-length` header, then `RqLive` must throw exception.

issues.title: HmRsBody matcher for checking response body
issues.body:
At the moment we have `HmRsHeader` and `HmRsStatus` which allows us to use Hamcrest to match against `Response` headers or status codes, respectively.

It would be good if we have a class `HmRsBody` that will allow us to match the `Response` body as well. Let's create one, with public constructors that can accept `Matcher<String>` and `Matcher<byte[]>`, to support both text and binary responses.

issues.title: Very confusing test failure message when using `HmRsHeader`
issues.body:
Consider the following test:

``` java
    @Test
    public void testRsHeader() {
        MatcherAssert.assertThat(
            new RsWithHeader("content-type", "text/html"),
            new HmRsHeader("content-type", "image/png")
        );
    }
```

It fails (pretty trivial). But this is the failure message:

```
TkSwitchTest.testRsHeader
testRsHeader(com.xockets.xjm.http.TkSwitchTest)
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expected: entry containing ["content-type"->"image/png"]
     but: was <RsWithHeader(super=RsWrap(origin=org.takes.rs.RsWithHeader$1@7637f22))>
```

The "expected" value was pretty clear in what the test was expecting. However, the actual value displayed is a generic object signature and is not useful at all. It would be much better if it outputted a list of the actual header fields in the response.

issues.title: Very confusing test failure message when using `HmRsStatus`
issues.body:
Consider the following test:

``` java
    @Test
    public void testRsStatus() {
        MatcherAssert.assertThat(
            new RsWithStatus(500),
            new HmRsStatus(200)
        );
    }
```

Obviously, this will fail. The failure message looks something like this:

```
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expected: <200>
     but: was <RsWithStatus(super=RsWrap(origin=org.takes.rs.RsWithStatus$1@76ccd017))>
    at org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(MatcherAssert.java:20)
    at org.hamcrest.MatcherAssert.assertThat(MatcherAssert.java:8)
...
```

This message is very confusing:
- Expected value - what is "200"? If I have just a handful of tests that test for a bunch of HTTP statuses, then it's clear. But if I have dozens of tests, this expected message does not give me any info on the significance of "200".
- Actual value - I see a bunch of generic Object descriptions, but I don't see what the actual HTTP status really is.

We should revise the code such that it looks similar to the following:

```
java.lang.AssertionError: 
Expected: <HTTP status code: 200 OK>
     but: was <HTTP status code: 500 Internal Error>
```

issues.title: Add a Response implementation that applies "modifying" Xembly directives
issues.body:
Right now, there is an implementation of Response that creates an XML from Xembly directives that build an XML from scratch.
Let's have an implementation that applies "modifying" Xembly directives to an existing XML document. That latter XML document could also be built from Xembly directives.

issues.title: FkContentType should have a Take rather than a Response
issues.body: FkContentType is built with a Response. To handle more general use cases like `Content-Type: text/html; charset=...`, it should be built with a Take that will handle the request dynamically.

issues.title: BkReuse should not be a wrapper
issues.body:
`BkReuse` should not decorate another `Back`. Persistent connections should either be handled by `BkBasic` or by a specific Back that don't decorate another Back.
**Reason:** before delegating the process of the socket to the underlying Back, BkReuse should definitely read from the socket input stream and process some of the headers.
There is no way to reposition the socket input stream to be (correctly) processed again by the underlying Back. The underlying Back would accept an already read socket.

> Let's get rid of BkReuse, move all tests from BkReuseTest to BkBasicTest and implement persistent connections inside BkBasic. Thanks for taking time to convince me.

issues.title: BkReuseTest does not send proper request
issues.body:
`BkReuseTest` as implemented in #417 does not send a request to `BkReuse` to be processed. All sockets in all three methods have empty input streams.
`BkReuseTest` should send sockets with valid content to `BkReuse` in order to test it.

issues.title: Connection reset if request body wasn't read from POST
issues.body:
For example, server expects POST request with some body
In some particular case server may be not interested in request body.
But if server didn't read the body then response is never sent - client will get connection reset.
Reading the body manually (`new RqPrint(req).printBody()`) works but not the best approach.

It would be nice if `takes` read request body somehow if it wasn't read during response generation.
As far as I know, servlets are doing this way.

issues.title: base parameter in RsXSLT.InClasspath.resolve(String, String) is unused
issues.body: `base` parameter in `RsXSLT.InClasspath.resolve(String, String)` is unused

issues.title: Cannot use Pass with TkRegex
issues.body:
Currently we cannot use a `Pass` along with a `TkRegex` like we can with a `Take`. The reason is that `TkAuth` expects a `Take`.

Ideally we'd have a class `TkAuthRegex` that provides functionality analogous to that in `TkAuth`.

issues.title: RqHref.Base reads first line of header without checking format
issues.body:
`org.takes.rq.RqHref.Base` just reads first header and takes second element after space splitting :
`this.head().iterator().next().split(" ", 3)[1]`
It should check if the header format satisfies HTTP specifications.

issues.title: MainRemote should allow additional arguments to be passed
issues.body:
Right now, `MainRemote.exec` only passes a single argument, `--port`. This makes main classes much more complicated to test if we happened to test or require extra arguments.

Let's allow more arguments to be passed by adding a second constructor `MainRemote(Class<?> type, String... args)`. All arguments passed to `args` should be passed to the main class being tested, with the addition of `--port`.

new TkFallback(

issues.title: TkRetry
issues.body:
Let's create a new decorator `TkRetry`, which will not fail immediately on `IOException`, but will retry a few times:

``` java
new TkRetry(
  original_take,
  3, // how many times to retry, maximum
  30 // initial delay between retries, in milliseconds
);
```

issues.title: RqOnce
issues.body:
Let's create a new wrapper of `Request`, which will make this code invalid:

``` java
Request req = new RqOnce(req);
req.body();
req.body(); // exception here
```

Only one time we can call `body()`. All other calls will lead to runtime exception.

issues.title: Application crashes when Response pipe is broken
issues.body:
I am trying to write a small monitoring application using Takes. Right now I'm having issues, because the application keeps crashing with the following error printed to the output:

```
Exception in thread "main" java.net.SocketException: Broken pipe
        at java.net.SocketOutputStream.socketWrite0(Native Method)
        at java.net.SocketOutputStream.socketWrite(SocketOutputStream.java:113)
        at java.net.SocketOutputStream.write(SocketOutputStream.java:159)
        at java.io.BufferedOutputStream.flushBuffer(BufferedOutputStream.java:82)
        at java.io.BufferedOutputStream.flush(BufferedOutputStream.java:140)
        at sun.nio.cs.StreamEncoder.implFlush(StreamEncoder.java:297)
        at sun.nio.cs.StreamEncoder.flush(StreamEncoder.java:141)
        at java.io.OutputStreamWriter.flush(OutputStreamWriter.java:229)
        at org.takes.rs.RsPrint.printHead(RsPrint.java:148)
        at org.takes.rs.RsPrint.print(RsPrint.java:110)
        at org.takes.http.BkBasic.print(BkBasic.java:104)
        at org.takes.http.BkBasic.accept(BkBasic.java:77)
        at org.takes.http.FtBasic.loop(FtBasic.java:105)
        at org.takes.http.FtBasic.start(FtBasic.java:91)
        at com.adecco.sam.util.aspire.CheckAvailability.main(CheckAvailability.java:119)
```

Line 119 is a call to `FtBasic.start()`. I don't think the application should crash when the response tries to write to the output, which means either this is definitely a bug or I'm doing something wrong.

**UPDATE**: Upon further investigation, it appears that the solution to this is to wrap the `Take` into a `BkSafe` before sending it to `FtBasic`. This is what `FtCLI` does. However, there's no clear documentation on how to use `BkSafe`  or `Back`, which is confusing to people who are building applications using this framework.

Thus, I propose a couple of things:
1. Document `Back` usage in `README`
2. Use `BkSafe` by default when using `FtBasic`, or provide an implementation `FtSafe` which does this and use it in the `README` examples.

This way developers won't be wondering why their app keeps crashing when the response pipe gets disconnected...

issues.title: RqMultipartTest#handlesRequestInTime fails sometimes on my machine
issues.body:
`RqMultipartTest#handlesRequestInTime` seems to actually be a performance test. I don't think we should test performance during Maven build because it makes the build environment-dependent. For instance, on my machine this test finishes in too long time because my computer has to swap quite a lot in order to do a Maven build. Instead of required 3000 ms it runs for about 2000-10000 ms, and that causes a build to fail most of the time with a message like this:

```
Failed tests: 
  RqMultipartTest.handlesRequestInTime:379 
Expected: a value less than <3000L>
     but: <5099L> was greater than <3000L>

Tests run: 255, Failures: 1, Errors: 0, Skipped: 3
```

I think we should either get rid of this test, or to rewrite it to test something other than performance.

issues.title: FtCLI new param --port=/tmp/foo.txt
issues.body:
Let's make it possible to run `FtCLI` with this param:

```
--port=/tmp/foo.txt
```

If port is not a number, it has to be treated as file name. If this file is present, we read the port number from there. If it's not present, we allocate a new random port and save it into the file.

The main reason for this is to make `FtCLI` more thread/process safe.

issues.title: Incorrect setting the expiration date for a cookies
issues.body:
There are 3 classes using setting the expiration date for a cookies: RsFlash, PsCookie, RsReturn. All of them use the following code for expiration date calculation :

``` java
 String.format(
                Locale.ENGLISH,
                "Expires=%1$ta, %1$td %1$tb %1$tY %1$tT GMT",
                new Date(
                    System.currentTimeMillis()
                        + TimeUnit.HOURS.toMillis(1L)
                )
            )
```

the expiration date declared as GMT but the value uses local timezone. As result we have incorrect expiration date for a cookies. It is really can be seen if the server and the client are located in different time zones. I believe the expiration date must be converted to GMT before using in `String.format()`

CORS decorator
issues.body:
At the moment Takes doesn't support [CORS](http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/) 
I believe a CORS decorator has to be. It allows browser's request to Takes-based resources on another domain.

I think we can start from this

```
class TkCors implements Take {
  TkCors(Take take, String ... domains)
}
```
- If the `Origin` header not present in the request skip all steps below.
- If the `Origin` header is present in the request and the domains list is empty add a single `Access-Control-Allow-Origin` header to the response with  the value of the `Origin` header.
- If in previous step the domains list is not empty then the `Origin` header should match for any of the values in list of domains. Add same header as step above. If header doesn't match skip all steps. 
- Add a single `Access-Control-Allow-Credentials` header with the string `true` as value.
- Add a single  `Access-Control-Allow-Methods` header with the string `OPTIONS,GET,PUT,POST,DELETE,HEAD` as value.

POST /uas/oauth2/accessToken?grant_type=authorization_code&client_id=clnid&redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.example.com%2F&client_secret=secret&code=xxxx HTTP/1.1

grant_type=authorization_code&client_id=clnid&redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.example.com%2F&client_secret=secret&code=xxxx

issues.title: Identity with empty fields shall not be valid
issues.body: We mark as invalid `Identity` in `Codec` only `Identity` which we are not able to decode. But this could be such situation when we can decode, but get `Identity` object with empty URN and empty Properties (e.g. using Base64 decoding) and we handle it like valid `Identity`. Lets make it as invalid as well.

issues.title: RsGzip incorrectly compresses binary data
issues.body: There is a bug in `RsGzip`, it fails to compress binary data that contains `0x00` bytes. This looks like a typo, let's reproduce it and fix.

issues.title: BkTimeable
issues.body:
Let's create a new decorator of `Back`, which will allow any particular call to `accept()` last for less than X milliseconds. Something like this:

``` java
new BkTimeable(new BkParallel(new BkBasic(takes)), 5000);
```

I think we should start "watching" threads for each call to `accept()` and terminate them when time is running out.

Also, let's add a new argument to `FtCLI`: `--max-latency` to configure this behavior from command line

issues.title: Href.path() must add slash prefix by default
issues.body:
This code doesn't work:

```
new Href("http://example.com").path("a").path("b").toString().equals("http://example.com/a/b")
```

In reality it's equal to `"http://example.com/ab"`

issues.title: RsFlash is not tested
issues.body: `RsFlash` is not tested, let's create a unit test for it. Besides that, the class doesn't use the logging level provided anyhow. It simply ignores this parameter. Instead, it has to package the message and the logging level together in a single string and send them in Base64 format to the cookie. Without that we may have issues with unprintable characters inside the message.

issues.title: RsWithCookie must reject if invalid characters
issues.body: `RsWithCookie` must reject (throw runtime exception) when its ctor is called with name or value containing invalid (unprintable) characters. Let's create a test reproducing this situation and also let's document what RFC we're using to check for character validity.
